comment.author: 31363949@N02
comment._content:
Hi,
This is the equestrian statue of Emperor Joseph II in the Josefsplatz, Vienna.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31363949@N02] Well done! www.flickr.com/photos/bddougherty/4386065444/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31363949@N02] Brilliant! It is! - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josefsplatz

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Wikipedia: Josefsplatz is centred on a full-sized equestrian statue and monument of Emperor Joseph II, erected by sculptor Franz Anton Zauner between 1795 and 1807.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/31363949@N02] Huzzah! Thanks a million - rummaging in the drawer for a Location Identified tag...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
And the inscription in Latin reads -
IOSEPHO . II . AVG QVI SALVOI[?] . PVBLICAS . VIXIT NON . DIV . SED . TOTVS
see www.flickr.com/photos/stvmasters/4635996068/ [searches for his Latin dictionary ...]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
On the right side of the base the emperor promotes commerce by exhorting Mercury to untie the hands of Trade, shown as a young woman in antique drapery seated on created goods near a waiting ship.

just in case you were wondering...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Google Translate really struggling with this one:

Joseph. 2. AVG
who in
SALVOI [?]. Are public. lived
NOT. 504. BUT. Rules

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The wikipedia article has a great modern comparison photo which shows a huge gold ball top left (see note) - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wien10Josefsplatz13.JPG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think it ma be "SALVTI" not SALVOI (huge serifs on the T) - so something like -

Joseph 2nd Aug[ustus?]
Who lived the safety of the State not divided but whole

comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content: This is also the statue where Harry Lime was supposedly carried to after being hit by the car.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] Yes! 'The Third Man'. See - youtu.be/sbfKibLRqqQ?t=2m

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970]  The plot thickens.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] This site translates the inscription (IOSEPHO II AVG QVI SALVTI PVBLICAE VIXIT NON DIV SED TOTVS) as "Kaiser Josef II., der für das allgemeine Wohl lebte, nicht lange, aber ganz" ("Emperor Joseph II who lived for the common good not long, but quite"). This site translates the last word as "complet" (sic)!

comment.author: 99423175@N02
comment._content: Real nice man

comment.author: 90124154@N00
comment._content: The statue and the inscription are both mentioned by Sigmund Freud in The Interepretation of Dreams (first published 1899) "On the pedestal of the Kaiser Joseph Memorial in the Imperial Palace in Vienna the following impressive words are inscribed: Saluti patriae vixit non diu sed totus (‘For the well-being of his country he lived not long but wholly’)"

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: He's the brother of "Let them eat cake" Marie Antoinette! King Louis's wife, well, till their heads um, "fell off"...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Well, his demise wasn't as sad as Elisabeth's was.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I thought I had a shot of it but I have one of his neighbour instead. Vienna is the place for fantastic sculpture, great pastries, lovely coffee and superb buildings!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I was wrong and I was right! I was wrong in my location but I was right in that I had a shot of this statue but not on flickr!
